title-group.article-title: Susanne K. Langer's Conception of 'Symbol'—Making Connections through Ambiguity

ref.mixed-citation: Lang quotes Langer, Problems of Art: But a work of art does not point us to a meaning beyond its own presence. What is expressed cannot be grasped apart from the sensuous or poetic form that expresses it. In a work of art we have the direct presentation of a feeling, not a sign that points to it. (pp. 133-34
Lang, p. 363)

Lang takes this to be the collapse of the symbol, and this collapse ought, Lang feels, to have produced a crisis in Langer's thought, but "the threat . . . does not produce the reper- cussions . . . which might be anticipated" (p. 362).

Goodman, in Ways of Worldmaking, acknowledges Cassirer's influence but says that "Cassirer undertakes the search through a cross-cultural study of the development of myth, religion, language, art, and science. My approach is rather through an analytic study of types and functions of symbols and symbol systems" (p. 6, quoted in Sebeok 1991).
Langer notes this inconsistency of Nagel's in her essay "On a New Definition of Symbol" (in Philosophical Sketches [1962] 1979, p. 60).

Hausman (1989) points out, when we allow the referent of a symbol (or metaphor) to be a perspective, we are in danger of "explaining away" what it is that we are trying to account for (p. 209).

Garry Hagberg ("Art and the Unsayable: Langer's Trac- tarian Aesthetics" [1984]) claims that Langer's conception of meaning is modeled on Wittgenstein's theory in the Tractatus and that in this theory "the word. . . must get its life by reaching out to another thing, its meaning" (p. 338).
